Graphical abstract In this work novel copper-alumina catalysts were prepared through a solvent-free solid-state grinding method ― a low cost and green catalyst preparation method for selective hydrogenation of 5-hydroxymethylfurfural (5-HMF) into 2,5-bis(hydroxymethyl)furan (BHMF). Under the optimized reaction conditions (3 MPa H2, 130 °C, 1 h), >99 % 5-HMF conversion and 93 % BHMF yield were obtained by using a 20CA (20 mol%Cu-Al2O3) catalyst. The catalyst characterization results could reveal that the high catalytic activity and selectivity could be attributed to the presence of both metallic and electrophilic copper (Cu°/Cu2+) species and the uniformly distributed copper nanoparticles. Furthermore, an integrated catalytic process was demonstrated for the first time for direct conversion of mono, di, and polysaccharides into the corresponding BHMF, obtained overall BHMF yield in the range of 25 %–48 %. Keywords Selective hydrogenation 5-Hydroxymethylfurfural 2,5-Bis(hydroxymethyl)furan Copper-alumina catalysts Solvent-free solid-state grinding 1 Introduction Due to the fast depletion of petroleum-based resources and the awareness of environmental problems triggered by the continuous consumption of fossil deposits, searching for new and alternative feedstocks to synthesize commodity chemicals, fuels, and polymers has attracted significant attention in the past few years [1,2]. Low cost, highly abundant, and carbon-neutral lignocellulosic biomass are considered an ideal feedstock for the synthesis of a variety of platform chemicals and useful industrial products [3]. 5-Hydroxymethylfurfural (5-HMF) is a versatile important platform chemical that can be synthesized directly from lignocellulosic biomass or biomass-derived C6-carbohydrates by the acid-catalyzed dehydration reaction [4,5]. The obtained 5-HMF can be used for the synthesis of various useful industrial chemicals e.g., 2,5-furandicarboxylic acid (FDCA) [6,7], hexanediol, 2,5-dimethylfuran, and 2,5-bis(hydroxymethyl)furan (BHMF) [4] by performing different types of chemical reactions such as oxidation and hydrogenation. For instance, 2,5-furandicarboxylic acid can replace the petroleum-derived terephthalic acid for the synthesis of bio-based polyethylenefuranoate (PET), which can be used for water bottles and packaging applications [8]. Also, 5-HMF can be used in the synthesis of phenol-hydroxymethyl furfural (PHMF), a green alternative to PF resins [9]. Since 5-HMF contains two types of functional groups such as CO and CC; however, hydrogenation of this molecule can produce different reaction products [10]. For example, the carbonyl group selective hydrogenation of 5-HMF can produce a diol - 2,5-bis(hydroxymethyl)furan (BHMF). BHMF can be used as an essential intermediate chemical for various potential industrial applications such as polymers, polyurethane foams, drugs, and other products of the fine chemical industry [10]. Traditionally, BHMF can be synthesized by the stoichiometric hydrogenation of 5-HMF in the presence of NaBH4 or LiAlH4 [11,12]. However, these reagents are moisture sensitive and generate much environmental waste. Alternatively, the catalytic hydrogenation of 5-HMF with hydrogen has been widely studied in recent years [10]. A homogeneous ruthenium-based dinuclear complex was found to be very active for the selective hydrogen of 5-HMF to BHMF, achieved 99 % BHMF yield under mild reaction conditions [13]. However, this catalyst is very expensive, difficult to recover and reuse, and hence has less industrial potential. Alternatively, heterogeneous catalysts that are simple to recover and can reuse for many catalytic cycles are more promising. In this regard, various supported heterogeneous noble metal (Ru, Pt, Pd, Au, Ir, and Re) based catalysts have been reported for selective hydrogenation of 5-HMF to BHMF [14–25,26]. Although all these catalysts would show remarkable catalytic activity and selectivity, preparation of these metal catalysts' is very costly. Thus, the development of inexpensive and heterogeneous recyclable supported metal-based catalysts for selective hydrogenation of 5-HMF is highly desirable. Copper-based heterogeneous catalysts are economical and selective catalysts for side-chain carbonyl group hydrogenation without affecting double bonds in 5-HMF molecule [10]. Cao et al. synthesized copper supported on silica (Cu/SiO2) catalyst for the selective hydrogenation of 5-HMF, obtained high BHMF yield after 8 h under 2.5 MPa H2 at 100 °C [27]. In another work, Lima et al. used a commercial Raney®-Cu catalyst for continuous flow hydrogenation of aqueous 5-HMF at 90 °C under 90 bar H2 pressure, attaining 94 % 5-HMF conversion and 84 % BHMF yield, respectively. In contrast, Raney ®-Ni catalyst was less selective under the same reaction conditions [28]. Hassan et al. synthesized bimetallic copper-iron oxide nanoparticles for selective hydrogenation of 5-HMF in the absence of external hydrogen at 150 °C for 5 h in ethanol solvent, and obtained 97 % 5-HMF conversion and 92 % BHMF yield, respectively [29]. Besides, various other heterogeneous copper-based catalysts have also been reported under different reaction conditions, achieving BHMF yields are in the range of 62–99 % [30–33]. Even though all these catalysts were active for the synthesis of BHMF, most of the reported studies were focussed on hydrogenation of commercially available 5-HMF. Recently, an integrated catalytic process for direct conversion of fructose to BHMF was reported [34]. High BHMF yields were reported, whereas fructose is an expensive feedstock for large scale production of BHMF. Therefore, catalytic conversion of inexpensive biomass-derived carbohydrates into BHMF is highly attractive. It should be noted that most of the reported copper-based catalysts for hydrogenation of 5-HMF to BHMF were prepared through conventional precipitation or co-precipitation and impregnation methods, which not only are time consuming, but generate much environmental waste and involve multiple preparation steps. Accordingly, the development of heterogeneous supported copper catalyst prepared through a simple and greener solvent-free method is highly desirable for the selective hydrogenation of 5-HMF to BHMF. Simple solid-state grinding synthesis of supported metal or metal oxide catalysts have attracted much attention in the past years [35–42]. In this method, various heterogeneous catalysts were prepared through simple physical mixing of metal precursors followed by heat treatment. Interestingly, these catalysts demonstrated better catalytic performance than those prepared via the conventional wet chemistry route. We recently reported the solid-state synthesis of tin phosphate and Co-Mn mixed oxide catalysts [43,44], which also showed much better catalytic performance than the same catalysts prepared in a conventional precipitation method. Moreover, the main advantages of the solid-state grinding method are: it is quick, inexpensive, easy to scale up, and no waste is produced during the catalyst preparation. To the best of our knowledge, no report on the solid-state grinding synthesis of copper-alumina catalysts for selective hydrogenation of biomass-derived 5-HMF into BHMF. Herein, we report synthesis of various copper-alumina (Cu-Al2O3) catalysts by the one-step solid-state grinding of copper and alumina precursors with oxalic acid followed by calcination and reduction. The as-synthesized catalysts were directly used for the selective hydrogenation of biomass-derived 5-HMF. The effects of various other reaction parameters such as catalyst support, copper loading, hydrogen pressure, solvent, reaction temperature, and time, and the influence of catalyst preparation methods were examined in this work to produce a high BHMF yield. Different catalyst characterization techniques were used to understand the structural properties of the catalysts and their catalytic activities. Additionally, a two-step integration method was demonstrated for direct conversion of simple and complex sugars into BHMF without isolation of the 5-HMF intermediate. 2 Experimental 2.1 Materials Reagent grade Al(NO3)3 9H2O, Cu(NO3)2 3H2O, oxalic acid, 5-hydroxymethylfurfural (99 %), glucose, microcrystalline cellulose, cellobiose, sucrose, starch, and 5-methylfurfural were all purchased from Sigma-Aldrich. Niobium phosphate hydrate (NbOPO4·nH2O) was supplied by CBMM (Companhia Brasileira de Metalurgia e Mineraçã). Ethanol, methanol, THF, Toluene, methyl isobutyl ketone (MIBK), Hexane, Water (HPLC grade), acetonitrile (HPLC grade) were obtained from Caledon Laboratories. All reagents were used as received without further purification. 2.2 Catalyst preparation Copper-alumina catalysts were prepared via the solid-state grinding method. Taking the 20 mol%Cu-Al2O3 catalyst as an example, it was prepared with the required amounts of copper nitrate, aluminum nitrate, and oxalic acid (OA) at a specific mole ratio (OA/Cu + Al = 1.4) by grinding manually in a mortar and pestle for about 10−15 min. We prepared each catalyst three times and tested their catalytic activity to ensure reproducibility of the sample preparation method and reported the average values of these catalytic results in the manuscript. The obtained blue coloured solid paste was dried in an oven at 90 °C overnight, followed by calcination in air at 600 °C for 2 h at 2 °C min−1. This catalyst was denoted as 20CA. Similarly, by varying the copper nitrate mole ratio, different catalysts were prepared, denoted as 10Cu-Al2O3 (10CA), 15Cu-Al2O3 (15CA) and 25Cu-Al2O3 (25CA). For comparison, the 20Cu-Al2O3 catalyst was also prepared by the conventional co-precipitation method, as reported elsewhere [45], and the resulting catalyst was denoted as 20CA-P. 2.3 Catalyst characterization The acidic and basic properties of the reduced copper-alumina catalysts (in H2 flow in a tubular furnace at 350 °C for 2 h) were measured by NH3-TPD and CO2-TPD. The temperature-programmed desorption (TPD) experiments were carried out on a ChemBET Pulsar TPR/TPD automated chemisorption analyzer equipped with a thermal conductivity detector. In a typical run, 0.1 g of catalyst sample was loaded into a U-shaped quartz tube, and the catalyst was pre-treated at 300 °C for 1 h under a flow of helium gas (99.9 %, 120 mL min−1). After pre-treatment, the catalyst sample was exposed to pure NH3 or CO2 gas at 50 °C for 10 min. The physisorbed NH3 or CO2 was removed by flushed with He gas at 100 °C for 30 min. The catalyst's total acidity or basicity was calculated from the amount of NH3 or CO2 desorbed from ambient temperature to 800 °C at a heating rate of 10 °C min−1. In addition, temperature-programmed reduction (TPR) analysis of the copper-alumina catalysts was measured on a ChemBET Pulsar TPR/TPD automated chemisorption analyzer in the following procedure: approximately 0.1 g of the unreduced catalyst was loaded into the U-shaped quartz tube, and the sample was pre-treated at 300 °C for 1 h with a heating rate of 10 °C min−1 under a flow of pure He gas (99.9 %, 120 mL min−1). Then, the furnace temperature was cooled down to 50 °C in the same He atmosphere. The treated sample was then heated from 50 °C to 800 °C at linear heating of 10 °C min−1 in 5 % H2/N2 with a flow rate of 120 mL min−1. Powder X-ray diffraction (XRD) patterns of all fresh catalysts were obtained using an X-ray diffractometer (Rigaku RINT 2500, Tokyo, Japan) with Ni-filtered CuKa radiation (λ = 1.5406 Å) with a scan speed of 2° min−1 and a scan range of 2–80° at 30 kV and 15 mA. N2 physisorption was performed using Quadrasorb SI automated surface area and a pore size analyzer. Before the N2 adsorption measurement, the sample was degassed at 200 °C until a stable static vacuum of less than 5 × 10−3 torr was achieved. Subsequently, N2 adsorption was performed at −196 °C. The surface area of the catalysts was measured using multipoint BET in the relative pressure range of 0.05–0.3. The total pore volume was estimated at a relative pressure of 0.99. XPS measurements were conducted on an Axis Nova spectrometer using a monochromatic AlKα source (15 mA, 14 kV), calibrated using Au as the standard. For energy calibration, the C1s photoelectron lines were used. The C1s binding energy was taken as 285 eV. TEM images were acquired using an FEI Tecnai Osiris S/TEM equipped with a super X-field emission gun (FEG), X-ray detection and Kratos charge neutralizer system. STEM analysis was executed at an accelerating voltage of 200 kV. Thermogravimetric analysis (TGA) of fresh and spent catalyst samples was performed using a Mettler Toledo TGA/DTA 851e model (Switzerland) with a Stare software (version 6.1) by heating the samples from 25 to 800 °C under an oxygen flow of 100 mL min−1 with a heating rate of 10 °C min−1. 2.4 Catalytic studies 2.4.1 Catalytic hydrogenation of pure 5-HMF to BHMF The selective hydrogenation of 5-HMF to BHMF was carried out in a batch type custom-made 25 mL mini reactor constructed with standard SS 316 L Swagelok tubing and fitting, equipped with a pressure gauge and magnetic stir bar. Before the reaction, the catalyst was reduced in the flow of H2 in a tubular furnace at 350 °C for 2 h. In a typical run, 0.25 mmol HMF, 5 mL methanol, and 16 mg 20CA reduced catalyst were charged into the reactor. The air inside the reactor was flushed three times with pure N2 and H2, and finally, the reactor was pressurized with 3 MPa H2. The reactor was placed in an oil bath on a hot plate and stirred magnetically at 130 °C for 1 h. After the reaction, the reaction mixture was cooled to room temperature and depressurized carefully. The catalyst was separated by filtration, and the liquid products were analyzed by gas chromatograph-mass spectrometer (GC–MS) (Agilent Technologies, 5977 A MSD with an SHRXI 5MS column (30 m × 250 mm × 0.25 mm)). The products were quantified by an external calibration method using known standards. The conversion of 5-HMF and the yield of products were calculated as follows: (1) H M F c o n v e r s i o n % = m o l o f H M F r e a c t e d I n i t i a l m o l o f H M F × 100 % (2) B H M F y i e l d ( % ) = m o l o f B H M F p r o d u c e d i n i t i a l m o l e o f H M F × 100 % 2.4.2 Synthesis of 5-HMF from different mono, di and polysaccharides The dehydration glucose, fructose, sucrose, cellobiose, starch and microcrystalline cellulose was carried out in a custom made 30 mL batch type reactor equipped with a pressure gauge and magnetic stir bar. In a typical run, 0.3 g feedstock, 3 mL water saturated with NaCl, 15 mL MIBK and 75 mg niobium phosphate (NbP) catalyst was loaded into the reactor. Before the experiment, the reactor was flushed and pressurized with 0.5 MPa nitrogen gas to remove the air inside the reactor and avoid boiling the reaction medium under the experimental conditions. The reactor was placed in an oil bath on a hot plate and stirred magnetically at 160 °C for 1−6 h depends on the feedstock solution. After completing the reaction, the reactor was removed from the hot plate and placed in an ice-water bath to quench the reaction. The catalyst was separated by simple filtration, and the reaction mixture containing 5-HMF in both aqueous and organic phases was quantified using high-performance liquid chromatography (HPLC) using HPLC (Waters 2690 HPLC) equipped with a refractive index detector (Waters 410) and photodiode array detector (Waters 2996) using an XBridge Amide analytical column (3.5 μm, 4.6 × 250 mm), 80/20 acetonitrile/water with 0.2 % triethylamine as mobile phase with a flow rate of 0.6 mL/min. The substrate conversion and 5-HMF yields were quantified by external calibration method with calibration curves constructed with pure glucose, fructose and 5-HMF substrates. 3 Results Surface and structural properties of copper-alumina catalysts were characterized by BET, XRD, CO2 and NH3-TPD, H2-TPR, XPS, and HAADF-STEM techniques to gain insight into the structural characteristics of the catalyst materials. 3.1 Structural characteristics of the catalyst materials It should be noted that all synthesized catalysts were reduced under H2 at 350 °C for 2 h prior to characterization with different instrumental techniques. 3.1.1 BET The textural properties of the catalyst can play a vital role in heterogeneous catalysis. Table 1 summarizes the BET surface area and total pore volume of the pure alumina and copper-alumina based catalysts prepared by solid-state grinding, co-precipitation and impregnation methods. As shown in Table 1, the BET surface area and total pore volume of the pure Al2O3 prepared by the solid-state grinding method are 18.1 m2/g and 0.03 cc/g, respectively. Both BET surface area and total pore volume of the copper-alumina catalysts are significantly higher relative to the pure alumina, whereas depending on the copper loading. For example, the specific BET surface area and total pore volume of the 10CA catalyst are 18.3 m2/g and 0.07 cc/g, respectively, while these values increase to 77.7 m2/g and 0.22 cc/g, respectively, when increasing the copper loading to 20 mol% for 20CA catalyst. Whereas, further increasing the copper loading to 25 mol%, both specific surface area and pore volume of the catalyst are significantly reduced to 41.2 m2/g and 0.16 cc/g, respectively. The average pore size of all these catalysts was also measured, as presented in Table 1. The BJH pore size distribution curves (Fig. S1) display that these catalysts contain both micropores and mesopores and all the catalyst samples have a pore size distribution in the range of 1−20 nm. On the other hand, the 20CA-P catalyst prepared by the conventional co-precipitation method for comparison has a specific surface area of (71.7 m2/g) that is slightly lower than that of the 20CA catalyst (77.7 m2/g), but there is a noticeable difference in the total pore volume of these two catalysts. For comparison, the 20CA-I catalyst was also prepared by impregnation of copper on commercial Al2O3 support that has a high surface area (200 m2/g). After impregnation of copper, the BET surface area is significantly reduced compared to the bare Al2O3 support. The pore size distribution of these three catalysts prepared through different methods is shown in Fig. S2. Both 20CA-P and 20CA-I catalysts contain micro- and mesopores and the particle size distribution is in the range of 1−100 nm. Overall, compared with the pure Al2O3, the one-step preparation of copper-alumina catalysts via the solvent-free solid-state grinding method could improve the textural properties by forming a CuOAl bond that enhances the catalyst porosity [46,47]. 3.1.2 XRD The powder X-ray diffraction measurements are used to determine the crystalline structure of the catalyst samples. Fig. 1 shows the XRD patterns of supported copper catalysts. As shown in Fig. 1, the bare Al2O3 does not exhibit any XRD peaks, indicating the amorphous nature of the support. On the other hand, the XRD patterns of copper-alumina catalysts reduced in the flow of H2 exhibit the main crystalline peaks at 2θ values of 36.6°, 43.3°, 50.3°, and 74.1°. The first peak at 2θ = 36.6° corresponds to the spinel structure of copper aluminate (CuAl2O4) phase JCPDS 33-0448 [48–50]. It can be observed that the crystallinity of the copper aluminate phase increases with the increase of copper loading. The other three XRD peaks at around 43.3°, 50.3°, and 74.2° correspond to the (111), (200), and (220) planes of metallic Cu, respectively, which can be indexed to the fcc structure of Cu (JCPDS No. 85–1326) [51,52]. The metallic copper peaks' intensity increases with the increase of copper loading from 10 to 20 mol% but slightly decreases with a further rise of copper loading to 25 mol%. In contrast, the 20CA-P catalyst displays only one broad XRD peak at 2θ of 36.8°, which corresponds to the copper aluminate phase, and no other peaks were detected, suggesting the amorphous nature of the catalyst or highly dispersed status of the copper species in the Al2O3 matrix. In contrast, the XRD pattern (Fig. S3) of the 20CA-I catalyst prepared by impregnation of copper on commercial γ-Al2O3 shows both metallic copper and γ-Al2O3 peaks, implying poorer dispersion of the copper particles in the 20CA-I than that of the 20CA-P. Furthermore, the crystallite sizes of copper-aluminate spinel and metallic Cu species of different copper-alumina catalysts were calculated using the Scherrer equation based on the highest intensity XRD peak at 2θ = 36.6° and 43.3°, respectively, and the crystallite size values are presented in Table 1. These results demonstrate that the crystallite sizes of both species increase with the increase of copper loading. 3.1.3 NH3-TPD The acidic properties of the copper-alumina catalysts were measured by NH3-TPD, and the results are presented in Fig. 2 . The total acidity values are summarized in Table 1. As shown in Fig. 2, the NH3-TPD pattern of the bare Al2O3 exhibits a one broad NH3 desorption peak in the temperature range of 300–800 °C, indicates the presence of medium and strong acid sites on the catalyst surface. However, the copper-alumina mixed oxide catalysts prepared by solid-state grinding followed by calcination and reduction, the acidity of these catalysts was slightly altered, depending on the copper loading. Except for the 10CA catalyst, all other copper-alumina catalysts exhibit low temperature and high-temperature NH3 desorption peaks. It indicates weak, medium and strong acid sites present on the catalyst surface. The low-temperature NH3 desorption peak could be attributed to Lewis acid sites, essential for hydrogenation reactions because they act as electron-pair acceptors [53]. Souza et al. [54] reported that with the incorporation of copper into alumina, the total acidity of the catalyst is decreased relative to pure Al2O3 caused by the covering of acid sites with metal clusters. Nevertheless, in the present study, increasing the copper content from 10 mol% to 25 mol%, the different copper-alumina catalysts' total acidity did not follow a particular trend. Compared with pure Al2O3, both 15CA and 20CA catalysts exhibit increased acidity, whereas 10CA and 25CA catalysts display reduced acidity values. Furthermore, the 20CA-P catalyst also exhibits weak, medium, and strong acid sites; however, while compared with the 20CA catalyst, some difference in the peak intensity was observed, especially at low and high- temperature regions. As shown in Fig. 2, the 20CA-P catalyst contains moderately strong acid sites, as indicated by a high-intensity peak at the high-temperature region. However, the total acidity of the 20CA-P catalyst is moderately low, if compared with the 20CA catalyst (Table 1). This difference might be attributed to the different methods adopted to prepare these catalysts. 3.1.4 CO2-TPD CO2-TPD measurements were used to evaluate the copper-alumina catalysts' surface basicity, and the corresponding CO2-TPD profiles are illustrated in Fig. 3 . The CO2-TPD profiles of all catalyst materials, including the pure Al2O3, display a strong CO2 desorption peak in the temperature range of 300–800 °C, which could characterize the presence of medium to strong basic sites [55]. The medium strength of basic sites could be originated from the interaction of CO2 with the Lewis acid-base pairs (M+- O-), forming the monodentate or the bidentate carbonate species [56]. The strong basic sites could be ascribed to the interaction of CO2 with the coordinately unsaturated O2− species [55]. The total basicity of all these catalysts was quantified, and the values are presented in Table 1. For comparison, the total basicity value of pure Al2O3 prepared by solid-state grinding is also listed in Table 1, being the maximum value of 0.49 mmol/g. The total basicity of the copper-alumina catalysts was altered significantly relative to that of the pure Al2O3. From Table 1, the total basicity of these catalysts decreases in the following order: Al2O3 > 10 CA > 20 CA-P > 20 CA > 25 CA > 15 CA. 3.1.5 H2-TPR H2-TPR technique provides information about the reducibility and metal-support interaction of a catalyst [57]. The H2-TPR profiles of the unreduced copper-alumina catalysts are shown in Fig. 4 . The copper-alumina catalysts prepared by solid-state grinding method exhibits a single reduction peak in the temperature range of 150 °C–500 °C, which could characterize the reduction of CuO to metallic copper [58]. As expected, the intensity of the hydrogen consumption peak increases with the increase of copper loading, which is consistent with the observations in the study of Dieuzeide et al. [51]. According to the literature survey, the maximum reduction temperature of coper-alumina catalysts is below 300 °C [57,59], whereas, in the present study, it is reduced at a maximum temperature of 345 °C, which is in good agreement with Dong et al. work [60]. Nevertheless, compared with the literature results [57,59,61], the reduction temperature of copper catalyst shifts to a high-temperature region, which might be due to the difference in the catalyst preparation methods. Indeed the copper-aluminate compounds formed by solid-state reactions during the calcination process would result in strong interaction and a higher reduction temperature [59,60]. On the other hand, the reduction peak slightly shifts to a lower temperature (325 °C) in the 20CA-P catalyst, indicating weak interaction between copper and alumina. 3.1.6 XPS XPS was used in this work to quantify the surface atomic composition and identify each element's oxidation state on the catalyst surface. The survey scan spectra of the 20CA catalyst display copper, alumina, and oxygen elements (Fig. 5 a). The deconvoluted XPS spectra of Cu 2p (Fig. 5b) show four different binding energy peaks. The binding energy peak at 930.8 eV and another peak at 950.01 eV could be ascribed to Cu 2p3/2 and Cu 2p1/2, signifying the presence of Cu0 oxidation state [58]. Whereas the XPS peaks at 932.4 and 952 eV corresponds to the Cu 2p3/2 and Cu 2p1/2 of Cu2+ oxidation state [62]. It should be noted that the presence of Cu1+ cannot be ruled out due to practically the same binding energies of both Cu0 and Cu1+ [62,63]. However, compared with literature results [64–66], the binding energy values of both Cu° and Cu2+ slightly shift to lower values, implying the strong interaction between Cu and Al2O3 due to the electrons transfer from alumina to the active metal, which is well supported by the results of H2-TPR measurements. In addition to the main peaks, small satellite peaks of Cu 2p3/2 and Cu 2p1/2 were detected at 938.1 and 962.5 eV, respectively, which are formed due to the ejection of photoelectron with another valence band electron and/or to the metal-to-ligand charge transfer, indicating the presence of Cu2+ ions in the 20CA catalyst [67]. Thus, the XPS results reveal that the catalyst surface is not completely reduced and contains oxidized Cu2+ ions. Furthermore, these results are well supported with the XRD results, where the presence of the CuAl2O4 phase was detected in the XRD pattern of the 20CA catalyst, which indicates that the presence of oxidized copper in the catalyst. Moreover, the XPS results also align well with the H2-TPR measurement, where the maximum reduction temperature of 20CA catalyst is 345 °C, and the copper ions are not entirely reduced before 350 °C, i.e., the reduction temperature used in this study (Fig. 4). Therefore, XPS, XRD, and H2-TPR results signify the presence of both metallic and oxidized copper species in the 20CA catalyst. 3.1.7 STEM Fig. 6 a shows the high-angle-annular darkfield scanning electron microscopy (HAADF-STEM) images of the 20CA catalyst, and the corresponding particle size distribution histogram is shown in Fig. 6b. As can be observed from Fig. 6a, many bright spots are dispersed on the alumina surface, indicating the atomic dispersion of metallic copper particles. The particle size distribution histogram displays that the copper particle size is in the range of 1−9 nm, and the average particle diameter is 2.6 nm. The elemental mappings of the 20CA catalyst are shown in Fig. 6c–e, which demonstrates uniform dispersion of copper on alumina across the surface (Fig. 6f). 3.2 Catalytic performance 3.2.1 Effects of reaction temperature and time The copper-alumina catalysts prepared through the solvent-free solid-state grinding method were evaluated for selective hydrogenation of biomass-derived 5-hydroxymethylfurfural to 2,5-bis(hydroxymethyl)furan (BHMF). Generally, the hydrogenation of 5-HMF can produce different reaction products, such as BHMF, 5-methylfurfural (5-MF), 5-methyl-2- furanmethanol (MFM), 2,5-dimethylfuran (DMF), and the ring-opening rearrangement products [68–70]. However, selective hydrogenation of 5-HMF to BHMF can be achieved by varying the reaction parameters, particularly the reaction temperature and time. In this study, initially, the effects of reaction temperature and time on selective hydrogenation of 5-HMF over 20CA catalyst were examined under the following reaction conditions: 5-HMF/cat. 2:1 w/w, methanol (5 mL), and H2 pressure (3 MPa). The hydrogenation of 5-HMF was carried out between the temperature range of 110–140 °C. As shown in Fig. 7 a, the conversion of 5-HMF was very low, especially at the lower reaction temperature (110 °C and 120 °C). However, it gradually increased with the increase of reaction temperature and time. Indeed an almost complete conversion of 5-HMF was achieved at 130 °C after a one-hour course of reaction time. If further increasing the reaction temperature and time, a constant conversion of 5-HMF could be achieved. In contrast, an extended reaction time (2 h) was required for the complete conversion of 5-HMF at lower reaction temperatures (110 °C and 120 °C). In this conversion, BHMF was the main reaction product, and 5-MF a byproduct, whose yields varied with reaction temperature and time. Fig. 7b and c shows the variation of BHMF and 5-MF yields with the reaction temperature and time. Both BHMF and 5-MF yields increased while increasing the reaction temperature from 110 °C to 140 °C. A maximum of 94 % and 91 % BHMF yield were obtained at 130 °C and 140 °C after one hour course of time. When extending the reaction time to 2 h, a considerable decrease in BHMF yield and a simultaneous rise in 5-MF yield were noticed. The formation of 5-MF results from the hydrogenolysis reaction of 5-HMF at higher reaction temperatures [71,72]. Accordingly, 130 °C for 1 h appears to be the best reaction conditions for selective hydrogenation of 5-HMF to BHMF over the 20CA catalyst. 3.2.2 Effects of copper loading Next, we studied the effects of copper loading for the selective hydrogenation of 5-HMF under the above-optimized reaction conditions of temperature and time (130 °C, 1 h), and these results are depicted in Fig. 8 . Again, it should be mentioned that 5-MF formed as a reaction byproduct. Both 5-HMF conversion and BHMF yield increased while increasing the copper content from 10 mol% to 20 mol%. More than 99 % of 5-HMF conversion and 93 % of BHMF yield were achieved over the 20CA catalyst. However, with a further increase of copper loading to 25 mol%, an almost constant conversion of 5-HMF and BHMF yields were achieved. In fact, the BHMF yield was slightly reduced. Thus, these results demonstrate that the 20 mol% Cu loading could be optimum for this reaction. The variation in the catalytic activity and the BHMF yield among different copper-alumina catalysts could be related to the differences in the structural properties of the catalysts. It was believed that metallic and electrophilic copper species are played a crucial role in the selective hydrogenation of 5-HMF to BHMF [31]. As illustrated previously in Fig. 1, the relative XRD peak intensity of metallic copper, particularly at 2θ = 43.3°, was found maximum in the 20CA and 25CA catalysts and copper-aluminate species were observed in all catalyst samples. Whereas, the presence of uniformly distributed metallic copper nanoparticles (Fig. 6) was believed to play a pivotal role in the greater production of BHMF [31]. 3.2.3 Effects of reaction media The reaction medium could significantly influence the selective hydrogenation of 5-HMF to BHMF [18]. In this study, the hydrogenation of 5-HMF was carried out in different solvents over the 20CA catalyst under the so far optimized reaction conditions, and these results are summarized in Table 2 . Initially, the hydrogenation of 5-HMF was conducted in polar protic solvents like water, methanol, and ethanol. A complete conversion of 5-HMF was achieved in pure water solvent, but the BHMF yield was very low (<35 %). Excellent yields of BHMF (93 % and 90 %) were achieved when the hydrogenation of 5-HMF was carried out in methanol or ethanol reaction medium, as similarly observed in the literature [18]. In contrast to the previous literature reports [16,18], the polar aprotic solvents such as methyl isobutyl ketone (MIBK), THF, and acetonitrile solvents were also efficient for hydrogenation of 5-HMF, producing 90 %, 74 %, and 89 % of BHMF yields, respectively. Since MIBK and THF were used as biphasic reaction media to synthesize 5-HMF from sugars [73], it would be advantageous to directly convert biomass-derived sugars into BHMF without isolation of 5-HMF intermediate. On the other hand, low yields of BHMF were reported with nonpolar organic solvents (toluene and hexane) [18]. Therefore, the polar protic (methanol and ethanol) and polar aprotic (MIBK and acetonitrile) solvents appear to be best for the selective hydrogenation of 5-HMF to BHMF over a 20CA catalyst. Since a little higher BHMF yield was obtained with the polar protic methanol solvent, methanol was used as the reaction medium to study the effects of other reaction conditions. 3.2.4 Influence of hydrogen pressure Hydrogen pressure also could influence the selective hydrogenation of 5-HMF to BHMF. In this study, the catalytic performance of the 20CA catalyst was investigated by varying the hydrogen pressure from 1 MPa to 4 MPa, while maintaining the other reaction parameters constant. The catalytic activity results are depicted in Fig. 9 . It clearly shows that the 5-HMF conversion increased with the increase of hydrogen pressure and reached a maximum with 3 MPa of H2 used. A further rise in hydrogen pressure to 4 MPa led to nearly constant conversion of 5-HMF. BHMF yield increased from 70 to 93 %, along with increasing H2 pressure from 1 MPa to 3 MPa, but an almost constant yield of BHMF (92 %) was obtained when further increasing hydrogen pressure to 4 MPa. Besides BHMF, 5-MF was also produced under all these reaction conditions, but at a yield below 10 %. In the absence of hydrogen, 5-HMF could convert to other products such as humins, although they were not detected by GC–MS likely due to their poor volatility. Consequently, 3 MPa of hydrogen pressure was chosen for studying other reaction parameters. 3.2.5 Effects of catalyst preparation method In this study, the 20CA-P catalyst was prepared through the conventional co-precipitation method and its catalytic activity was compared with the 20CA catalyst prepared by the solvent-free solid-state grinding method. As shown in Fig. 10 , both catalysts attained complete conversion of 5-HMF but exhibited a slight variation in the product distribution. The 20CA catalyst prepared by the solvent-free grinding method is slightly superior to the 20CA-P catalyst, although ICP-AES analysis found that these two catalysts contain different amounts of copper (18.4 mol% Cu in 20CA vs 15.1 mol% Cu in 20CA-P). Thus, the little variation in the BHMF yield might be attributed to the difference in copper content between these two catalysts. 3.2.6 Integrated catalytic process for conversion of mono, di, and polysaccharides to BHMF So far, most of the literature studies were focused on the hydrogenation of commercially available expensive 5-HMF. However, direct synthesis of BHMF from biomass-derived carbohydrates via catalytic dehydration through the formation of 5-HMF intermediate followed by hydrogenation is more economically attractive and sustainable. Niobium phosphate (NbP) catalyst proved active for converting glucose and industrial-grade sugars into 5-HMF in a continuous flow process [74]. In this study, the dehydration of biomass-derived mono, di and polysaccharides (10 wt%) was first carried out in a biphasic reaction medium water and MIBK using a NbP catalyst in a batch process at 160 °C for 1–6 h. After the dehydration reaction, the NbP catalyst was separated by simple filtration, and the filtrate could be used directly for the second step hydrogenation reaction. However, since water is not a suitable reaction medium for the conversion of 5-HMF to BHMF over the 20CA catalyst (Table 2, entry 1), it was removed by evaporation after the dehydration reaction, followed by the extraction of 5-HMF with MIBK. The organic phase containing 5-HMF was then directly used without any further treatment for the second step hydrogenation reaction. As shown in Table 3 , monosaccharide glucose was effectively dehydrated over the NbP catalyst to form 5-HMF, resulting in 51.5 % yield, followed by hydrogenation over 20CA catalysts, producing BHMF at 15 % overall yield under the reaction conditions of (3 MPa H2 pressure, 1300C, 1 h). On one hand, it needs to note that the ketone group in a MIBK solvent is unreactive under these conditions. On the other hand, the low catalytic activity of the 20CA catalyst under these conditions is more likely due to the competition between the adsorption of the 5-HMF and some MIBK-soluble impurities generated during the first-step dehydration reaction. However, increasing the reaction temperature from 130 to 150 °C and extending the reaction time to 4.5 h, achieved complete conversion of 5-HMF and obtained a maximum overall yield (42.2 %) of BHMF. Henceforth, these reaction conditions were used for the conversion of other biomass-derived 5-HMF to BHMF. It was found that the monosaccharide fructose could also easily undergo dehydration over the NbP catalyst, producing 58 % 5-HMF yield and attained 48 % overall yield of BHMF after hydrogenation of 5-HMF. In addition, disaccharides such as cellobiose and sucrose could be easily converted into BHMF under the above established reaction conditions, achieving 40 % and 39.7 % overall yield, respectively. Furthermore, the integrated catalytic process was also demonstrated applicable for converting polysaccharides such as starch and microcrystalline cellulose, obtained 34.4 % and 25.2 % BHMF overall yield, respectively. From these above results, it can conclude that it is viable to produce BHMF from carbohydrates via an integrated catalytic process. Our group has recently developed a bifunctional carbon-based solid acid catalyst for production of 5-HMF (93 %) from glucose [75]. Such carbon-based solid acid catalyst will be tested in the integrated process along with the 20CA catalyst to produce BHMF from carbohydrates. 4 Discussion 4.1 Reaction mechanism 5-HMF contains reactive CC and CO functional groups; however, the bond energy of CO (715 kJ mol−1) is much higher than that of CC (615 kJ mol−1), allowing the hydrogenation of furan ring take place easier especially in the presence of a metal catalyst [76]. Nevertheless, owing to the conjugation of the carbonyl group with furan ring in a 5-HMF molecule, the selective hydrogenation of CO for the synthesis of BHMF could occur at the lower reaction temperature. Based on XPS results, the 20CA catalyst contains both Cu2+ and Cu° species on the catalyst surface. These could be active sites for hydrogenation of carbonyl group in a 5-HMF molecule in the presence of external hydrogen. Controlled experiments were carried out to understand the role of both Cu2+ and Cu° species' in the selective hydrogenation of 5-HMF. With unreduced 20CA catalyst in the absence of Cu° species, only <5 % yield of BHMF was obtained, although the 5-HMF was completely converted. Very recently, Li et al. [77] and Hellgardt et al. [78] reported RANEY® Cu catalyst for hydrogenation of 5-HMF to BHMF, obtained 59 % and 84 % BHMF yield, respectively. Nevertheless, in the present study, while using the metallic copper nanopowder (Cu°) as a catalyst, very low yield of BHMF (<15 %) were obtained under the established reaction conditions. Surprisingly, with physically mixed copper nanopowder and unreduced 20CA catalyst in an equal mass and a substrate-to-catalyst mass ratio of 2, the BHMF yield was abruptly improved to 62 %, much higher than that with the unreduced 20CA or copper nanopowder alone. These mechanistic studies demonstrate that the co-existence of both metallic and electrophilic copper species is likely a prerequisite for selective hydrogenation of 5-HMF, as similarly proposed in the literature [79,80]. Based on the above experimental results and the literature reports [79,81,82], a plausible reaction mechanism for selective hydrogenation of 5-HMF to BHMF over copper-alumina catalyst is proposed, as shown in Scheme 1 . Initially, the presence of electrophilic Cu2+ species in a copper-alumina catalyst assists the adsorption and activation of the CO group of 5-HMF via the lone pair of oxygen. Then, the hydrogenation of the activated carbonyl group is induced by a metallic copper (Cu0) using the dissociated hydrogen on its surface, leading to the formation of BHMF. 4.2 Heterogeneity and catalyst recyclability tests The stability of the 20CA catalyst against the metal leaching was examined under the following reaction conditions: 5-HMF/cat. 2:1 w/w, methanol (5 mL), H2 pressure (3 MPa) and 130 °C. 5-HMF conversion of 61 % with 59.2 % BHMF yield was obtained after 30 min in the presence of 20CA catalyst. After the quick removal of the catalyst by filtration, the filtrate was subject to ICP-AES analysis, and confirmed that the copper content in the filtrate was below the detection limit, indicating no apparent copper leaching loss during the reaction. The catalyst stability was further investigated by examining the recyclability according to the known procedure reported elsewhere [80]. After the initial catalytic run, the 20CA catalyst was separated from the reaction mixture by filtration. The retrieved catalyst was washed several times with methanol followed by vacuum dried at 80 °C overnight. The spent catalyst was reduced at 350 °C in the flow of H2 for 2 h and directly used for the next cycle. As shown in Fig. 11 , both 5-HMF conversion and BHMF yield decreased slightly after each successive cycle. There were decreases in the 5-HMF conversion and BHMF yield by 10 % and 14 %, respectively, after fourth cycles the catalyst. Thus the catalyst was slightly deactivated after each consecutive catalytic cycles, perhaps due to the loss of catalyst or the deposition of the carbon on the catalyst surface. The spent catalyst after four cycles were characterized by TGA, XRD, and XPS techniques. The TGA profile of the spent catalyst (Fig. 12 a) shows approximately 5 % more weight loss up to 400 °C than the fresh catalyst, which might be due to the deposition of high boiling-point methanol insoluble compounds or impurities formed on the catalyst surface during the reaction. The XRD pattern of the spent catalyst (Fig. 12b) reveals that no additional peaks appeared, and the crystalline structure of the catalyst remains almost no change, although the intensity of the metallic copper peaks slightly decreases and the XRD peak at 2θ = 36.8° corresponding to the copper-aluminate phase increases to a certain extent. In addition, there is no apparent differnece between the Cu 2p XPS spectra of the fresh and used catalysts (Fig. 12c). The surface atomic compositions of fresh and used catalysts were quantified based on XPS peak areas of individual elements on the catalyst surface, as presented in Table S1. It was evident that after successive catalytic cycles, the contents of copper and aluminum decreased, while the carbon content increased, which might account for the loss of both 5-HMF conversion and BHMF yield over the spent catalyst after four cycles. 4.3 Comparison of catalytic activity of 20CA catalyst with different heterogeneous catalysts reported in the literature The activity of the 20CA catalyst for the selective production of BHMF from 5-HMF was compared with some heterogeneous catalysts reported in the existing literature, as shown in Table 4 . Noble metal-based catalysts such as Ru, Au, and Pd catalysts exhibited excellent catalytic activity and selectivity, and achieved 82–96 % BHMF yield. Nevertheless, some of these processes operated under high H2 pressure as high as 10 MPa [21]. In contrast, the present 20CA catalyst produced a high BHMF yield (93 %) at a lower H2 pressure (3 MPa), and it is much less expensive than noble-metal catalysts, thus it is more promising. Moreover, the 20CA catalyst is easy to prepare. In another report, cobalt-alumina (CoAl) mixed oxide catalyst obtained 83 % BHMF yield [84], much lower than that of the current 20CA catalyst. Bimetallic copper-zinc alloy nanopowder is more selective for hydrogenation of 5-HMF, achieving 95 % BHMF yield but at H2 pressure of 7 MPa for a longer reaction time (3 h) [68], as compared with 93 % BHMF yield with the 20CA catalyst in this work under lower hydrogen pressure (3 MPa) for a shorter reaction time (1 h). Supported bimetallic copper-zinc (Cu-Zn@C) and copper-nickel (CuNi@Al2O3) catalysts produced much low BHMF yields than the present 20CA catalyst, even though the reactions were performed under higher temperature and pressure [61]. Moreover, the above-cited catalysts were prepared generally by precipitation or co-precipitation methods involving environmental waste generation. In constrast, the 20CA catalyst was prepared through the solvent-free solid-state grinding method without generation of environmental waste, hence more environmentally friendly. Overall, the 20CA catalyst developed in this work is superior to other heterogeneous catalysts reported in the literature. It could achieve catalytic activity and selectivity comparable to noble metal-based catalysts, but it is much less expensive and prepared in a more environmentally friendly method. 5 Conclusions In summary, stable and high-performance copper-alumina catalysts were prepared through a green and sustainable solvent-free solid-state grinding method. The catalysts showed superior performance than other heterogeneous catalysts reported in the literature (prepared generally by precipitation or co-precipitation methods) for selective hydrogenation of 5-HMF to BHMF. It could achieve catalytic activity and selectivity comparable to noble metal-based catalysts, but it is much less expensive. The catalytic activity and selectivity of the copper-alumina catalysts are highly dependent on the copper loading, reaction temperature and time, H2 pressure, and the type of solvent being used. Under the best reaction conditions (5-HMF/catalyst 2:1 w/w, methanol 5 mL, 3 MPa H2, 130 °C, 1 h), >99 % 5-HMF conversion, and 93 % BHMF yield were achieved over the 20CA catalyst. The catalyst characterization results revealed that the coexistence of Cu°/Cu2+ species would be accountable for its high activity for the selective production of BHMF. More significantly, an integrated catalytic process was demonstrated for the first time for direct conversion of mono, di, and polysaccharides into the corresponding BHMF, obtained overall BHMF yield in the range of 25 %–48 %. coredata.dc:description: In this work novel copper-alumina catalysts were prepared through a solvent-free solid-state grinding method ― a low cost and green catalyst preparation method for selective hydrogenation of 5-hydroxymethylfurfural (5-HMF) into 2,5-bis(hydroxymethyl)furan (BHMF). Under the optimized reaction conditions (3 MPa H2, 130 °C, 1 h), >99 % 5-HMF conversion and 93 % BHMF yield were obtained by using a 20CA (20 mol%Cu-Al2O3) catalyst. The catalyst characterization results could reveal that the high catalytic activity and selectivity could be attributed to the presence of both metallic and electrophilic copper (Cu°/Cu2+) species and the uniformly distributed copper nanoparticles. Furthermore, an integrated catalytic process was demonstrated for the first time for direct conversion of mono, di, and polysaccharides into the corresponding BHMF, obtained overall BHMF yield in the range of 25 %–48 %.
coredata.dc:title: Green synthesis of heterogeneous copper-alumina catalyst for selective hydrogenation of pure and biomass-derived 5-hydroxymethylfurfural to 2,5-bis(hydroxymethyl)furan
